description.narrative: The principle of access and benefit sharing (ABS) of the value chain targeted by this project is based on Echinops giganteus and Mondia whitei.

activity-description.narrative: The local communities of Magha-Bamumbu and Lewoh and their surroundings
The population of Magha-Bamumbu village in Lebialem Division, South West Region,

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative: By project end, the following indicators will be available: - signed PIC and MAT documents for Echinops giganteus and Mondia whitei. - Income accruing to the local community from the two value chains. - Enhanced capacity for ABS in Cameroon as measured by the UNDP ABS Scorecaerd. - Number of community representatives trained on ABS. - National Plan on ABS. - Number of national Communication plan with tools on ABS. - Number of local radio station enhanced on sensitization and awareness of community on ABS. - Number of document on ABS lessons learnt and best practices elaborated. - Number of communities targeted to share and apply the ABS lessons learnt and best practices elaborated. - Guidance document targeted to the community on IPRs and how to incorporate this in ABS value chains. - Number of participative and inclusive dialogue organized between local community, private users, government and other stakeholders on the access and use of GRs and a TK at local level and at national level. - Community protocol, where appropriate and where acknowledge, or a similar Prior Informed Consent approach based on GR and a TK local community for Mondia whitei. - Number of communities engaged to apply community protocol, where appropriate and where acknowledged, or a similar Prior Informed Consent approach based on GR and a TK local community for Mondia whitei. - MAT for Mondia whitei and PIC for Echinops g. - Sustainable management plans guide harvest of Echinops giganteus and Mondia whitei with atleast two tools for application. - Number of tools of Sustainable management plans guide harvest of Echinops giganteus and mondia whitei applied on the two targeted sites by local communities

comment.narrative: - 1 MAT and 0 PIC for Echinops giganteus. - 0 MAT and 0 PIC for Mondia whitei. - no income accruing to local communities neither through Echinops nor Mondia. - 27 for UNDP ABS Scorecard. - No local community trained on ABS. Local provider community (Magha-Bamumbu) and local Erudef are being assisted by French NGO Man and Nature in sustainable production of raw material and sustainable managemnt of resource. - Dialogues and negotiations between parties have been supported by to obtain the first ABS agreement between Cameroon government and French Company V. Mane Fils for research and commercialization phase (MAT signed in April 2015). - Absence of ABS legislation in Cameroon. - Drafting of an interim decree to regulate access to Genetic resources and traditional knowledge. - lack of means and capacity to properly address the involvement of local community beyond acutal participation in meetings. - ERUDEF, local NGO is currently building up the value chain (inventory,sustainable harvest and production practices).

T1- Enhance the capacity of 100 Community représentatives of the communities around Magha-Bamumbu and Lewoh on the implementation of the Nagoya Protocol. T2- Review and update the national ABS Strategy and its Action Plan. T3- Develop a graphical charter on communication for ABS in Cameroon. T4- Strengthen the capacity of the staff of 06 local and national stations to carry out awareness raising and sensitization on ABS. T5- Reproduction and distribution of best production and transformation processess of Echinops giganteus and Mondia whitei to surrounding communities of Magha-Bamumbu and Lewoh.
T6- Develop a technical guidance note on Intellectual Property Right and ABS. T7- Enhancement of the capacity of stakeholders to incorporate intellectual property rights into the ABS process.
T8- Organise a local dialogue with local communities, private sector, researchers, civil society and national stakeholders on ABS.
T9-Enhance the capacity of surrounding communities to elaborate a Biocultural Community Protocol. T10- Organise meetings to support the negotiation procedure and signing of PIC for Echinops and MAT for Mondia. T11- Organise 04 sessions of Committee meeting to examine files requesting for PIC and MAT by users. T12- Elaborate a well-defined procedure to request for PIC and MAT. T13- Train local communities on the use of the sustainable integrated management plan guide. T14- Organise a round-table conference with decision-makers (parliamentarians, senators and REPAR) to advocate for the promulgation of the draft ABS law). T15- Organise a round-table conference with decision-makers (Prime Minister's Office) to advocate for the adoption of the draft ABS law). T16- Organise an information and sensitization workshop on the draft ABS law and its regulatory text. T17- Organise a workshop to mainstream document into sectorial programme of Development. T18- Translation and reproduction of documents (communication plan and Tools, document on best methodology and transformation practice, technical guidance note on IPR, on ABS, etc.).
T19- Working session to examine and adopte 04 studies.
T20- Elaboration of document on lessons learnt.
T21- Organisation of sensitization of traditional healers on lessons learnt for further replication. T22- Elaboration of document to summarize discussions and findings from regional dialogues. T23- Production of visibility kits (T-shirts, gadgets, flyers).
T24- Training and sensitization for capacity building for a South-South cooperation and resources mobilization. T25- Evaluation of project.

R1- 04 Studies realised in 2018 were re-examined and proof-read by a small working group through a working session that lasted for two days 21-22 January 2019. R2- A Project Steering Committee meeting was organised on 9th April to provide strategic guidance regarding activities to be realised on project target zone given the socio-political crisis ongoing in the two English-speaking regions of the Country as well as to examine requests for PIC submitted by users to the ABS Focal point.
R3- The capacity of the staff of some 06 local radio stations were enhanced to carry out awareness raising and sensitization on the Nagoya Protocol on ABS from 24-26 April 2019 in Douala. R4- Some Documents have been translated and edited (Substantive Report on TK, Integrated Sustainable Management Plan Guides for Echinops and Mondia and Communication Plan).

T1- Train 50 community representaives on ABS. T2-Develop one communication plan with tools on ABS for local communities . T3- Train staff of 04 radio local radion stations on sensitization and awareness on ABS. T4- Develop a guide on best production and transformation process addressing replication of Echinops giganteus and Mondia whitei. T5-Develop one technical guide on ABS and Intellectual Property Right. T6- Train ABS stakeholders on IPR. T7- Sensitize Enterprises on ABS. T8- Elaborate a strategic document to involve Private sector in the valorisation of genetic resources. T9- Organise a training workshop for local communities and NGO on Biocultural Community Protocols. T10- Develop a Biocultural Community Protocol for Lewoh village. T11- Carry out missions to project target area to support the signing of Mat for Mondia research and commercialization. T12- Elaboration of a PIC/MAT for Echinops and Mondia.
T13- Organise preparatory meetings of M&E with the University of Dschang and local communities.
T14- Carry out a monitoring and evaluation mission to Nice-France, Magha and Lewoh to assess the implementation of MAT for commercialisation of Mondia. T15- Develop one integrated sustainable management plan for Echinops and Mondia.
T16- Elaborate a Database to characterize the genes of Echinops and Mondia to a focus on their economic potential.
T17- Elaborate the draft ABS law and its regulatory texts.
T18- Organise two meetings to examine draft regulatory texts.
T19- Organise a pre-validation and validation workshops for the draft ABS law and its regulatory texts.
T20- Train ABS taskforce, MINEPDED and its sector administration on implementation of Nagoya Protocol, rights of communities and their involvement and role as defined by the Protocol.
T21- Produce project visibility kits (T-shirts, caps, flyers, gadgets, roll-ups).
T22- Elaborate a Substantive Report to document national mechanism to protect, maintain and promote Traditional Knowledge.
T23- Translate and Reproduce key document for distribution.

R1- 50 Community représentatives (25 from Magha-Bamumbu and 25 from Lewoh) were trained on the effective implementation of the Nagogoya Protocole on a 5-day workshop with the help of a facilitator who used the previously developed training programme for local communities to develop contents for the workshop. Themes of the training included: (1) Value chain stakeholder responsibility mapping; (2) Community rights in relation to genetic resources and T; (3) Negotiations on PIC and MAT and (4) Best conservation, sustainable use and harvesting practices, collection, logistics, sample quality and traceability systems. R2- An expert was hired to develop a communication plan for local communities with Tools developed in local languages. The deliverables were examined in a national workshop with members of the communities, the ABS committee and the plan and Tools were adopted. R3- During a 3-day workshop 05 staff each from 04 local radio stations (making a total of 20 participants) whose wavelengths crosses the project target zone where trained on the implementation of the Nagoya Protocol on ABS. The objective was to build their capacity in order to enable them to continue awareness raising on the Nagoya Protocol for the benefit of the local communities and those around the Lebialem Division. R4- During a 2-days workshop organised with the representatives especially those involved at the different stages of the two value chains in the 2 communities (collectors/harversters, transformers, etc.) and with the help of a facilitator lessons of best methodology of production and transformation geared towards replication were captured by the expert who later distilled the information into a guide. This guide was adopted by the ABS focal point and taskforce and then later edited and printed into 500 copies and distributed to the two communities. R5- This target was not achieved. An expert was hired in December 2017 to elaborate a technical guidance note on ABS and IPR, unfortunately she has not delivered even a first draft. The issue was raised in the project steering committee meeting and it was decided that her contract should be terminated and an official correspondence written to ask her reimburse to the project the upfront 20% given to her upon the signing of the contract. R6- This target also was not achieved since it dépends on the previous target. The elaborated guidance note on ABS/IPR had to be used to train stakeholders on how to go about issues regarding IPR and ABS. R7- The target was achieved, From 28 to 31st May 2018, a joint team of représentatives of the Ministry of Environment, UNDP and GIZ carried out a mission to the economic capital city of Douala to raise the awareness of enterprises of the food, brewery, cosmetics and pharmaceutical industries on ABS. It was rounded up with a Forum to sensitize more enterprises on ABS. The forum was presided over by the Minister for Environment and jointly organised by the later and the organ in charge of organising the private sector-GICAM. During this mission/forum on awareness raising, over 50 industries both small, medium and large enterprises ranging from the food/brewery to cosmetics and pharmaceuticals were sensitized. R8- This output which was a recommendation of the Project Steering Committee of 2017 was achieved. This idea to elaborate a national strategy to involve actively the private sector on the ABS process was motivated by the fact that in absence of multinationals the process shouldn't be left out nationally. In this regard, terms of references were elaborated and an expert was hired. The deliverables were examined by the project board together with the taskforce and other relevant stakeholders and the strategy was adopted alongside other studies during a 4-days workshop. R9- A facilitator was contracted to train représentatives of local communities of Magha-Bamumbu and Lewoh, some NGOs, the taskforce and other stakeholders on the elaboration of a Biocultural Community Protocol. It is hoped that these NGOs will build the capacities of the communities around where they operate to enable them elaborate their own Biocultural Community Protocol. R10- After the elaboration of the TOR, a public call to tender was launched and an expert hired. He worked with the people of the Community of Lewoh (Youths, women, traditional council, traditional chiefs and healers, as well as the fon) and together a draft of the BCP for Lewoh was elaborated. During a 2-days workshop, représentatives from Lewoh, Magha-Bamumbu, the Project Board; taskforce and other stakeholders examined the draft protocol and validated the BCP for the Lewoh Community. R11-This output was not achieved. Meetings programmed to the project target zone geared at accompanying the Community of Lewoh for the signing of the MAT for Mondia Researh and Commercialization were not realised since the MAT was not signed. R12- An expert was hired to elaborate the PIC/MAT for Echinops and Mondia. Both draft documents are available and are awaiting signature. R13- This output was not achieved. It was in line with the monitoring and evaluation of the clauses of the PIC for Echinops and MAT for Mondia in the case of signature. Unfortunately both documents were not signed therefore no meetings were organised.
R14- This output was not achieved because the signing of the PIC for Echinops and MAT for Mondia were not signed. R15- This output was achieved. TOR for the recruitement of an expert were elaborated, a call to tender made and the expert hired through a selection process. The draft document submitted by the expert was examined and adopted together with other studies through a national workshop of members of the sectoral ministries, MINEPDED, taskforce and NGOs. R16- This output which was a recommendation of the Project Board meeting that held on December 29 2017 was not achieved. After the elaboration of TOR and call to tender, during the selection process, no qualified candidate was found and the selection team adviced the project implementation unit to review the TOR even thougyh the studies require a much higher cost that the project might not be able to meet up with. R17- This output was achieved. the international and national experts in charge of elaborating a draft ABS law were recruited in 2017 and they continued their job in 2018. They were accomapanied in this assignment by an ad hoc working group that was put in place assist in ensuring that all recommendations from the various meetings organised were integrated in the draft document. An expert was also hired to elaborated the draft text of implementation of the draft ABS law. His mandate was extended Following a recommendation by the Adhoc working group of the Law to elaborate not only the text of implementation but a model PIC, MAT and an ABS Permit. All these documents were elaborated and validated technically by members of the Project Steering Committee and other relevant stakeholders. R18- This output was achieved and it enabled the drafting of the regulatory text and other connexe documents such as model PIC, MAT and ABS permit. R19- The pre-validation workshop for the draft ABS law and its related documents was organised and the documents validated technically. What is left is the national validation which will be organised in 2019. R20- This output was achieved. A 3-day workshop was organised to train the ABS taskforce, MINEPDED and its sectoral ministries in the implementation of the Nagoya Protocol. The modules were designed following the training programme that was elaborated by an expert to that effect. R21- This output was also achieved. 2 roll-ups were produced: 1 is Always displayed in the office of the Project Assistant and 1 in the office of the Project Director in the Ministry of Environment. 500 copies in English and 500 in French were produced and Distributed. Also 300 T-shirts were also produced and Distributed to the local communities and other stakeholders. R22- This output was also achieve. An expert was hired who elaborated the substantive report to document a national mechanism to protect, maintain and Promote traiditional knowledge. the draft document was then examined and adopted during a national workshop with others. R23- The technical guidance note to simplify the Nagoya protocol was translated into French before production and distribution.
